column6: An introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
A continuation of the introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on translation into English.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on both prose (e.g., Caesar, Cicero) and poetry (Vergil, Catullus).
Readings in Cicero's orations and philosophical works, stressing rhetorical techniques. Consideration of Cicero's role in Roman history and his place in Latin literature.
A study of the Latin text of Vergil's Aeneid stressing the poetry of the language. Consideration of entire poem and its impact on Latin literature.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in Latin studies. S u graded.
Topic announced in the schedule of classes.

column4: minimum 3 hours of coursework at the 40000-level and departmental special approval.
column6: Investigation of problems in Latin literature or linguistics.
Analysis of prose models; writing of connected Latin prose with attention to the Latin idiom.
Characteristics and history of Latin comedy; readings from Plautus and Terence.
Selections from Tibullus, Propertius and Ovid.
Readings from the poetry of Catullus and Horace, with considerations of the general genre of lyric; a comparison of style and content of the two poets.
Consideration of a major prose author such as Pliny the Younger, Livy, Tacitus or Suetonius; may be repeated when a different author is read.
General consideration of Roman satire.
De Rerum Natura.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in Latin studies.

column4: LAT 36180 and LAT 37171 and graduate standing.
column6: Topic to be announced in semester schedule of classes. May be repeated to maximum of 15 hours.
General consideration of Roman satire.
De Rerum Natura.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
More thorough training in composition where need is established.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
Characteristics of Latin comedy; readings from Plautus and Terence.

Readings from the poetry of Catullus and Horace, with considerations of the general genre of lyric; a comparison of style and content of the two poets. Study of Greek and Latin precedents in the genre.
A consideration of selected major prose writers such as Pliny the Younger, Livy, Tacitus Suetonius.
Topics to be announced.
Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students. Credits earned applied toward degree requirements if department approves. Repeated registration permitted.
